pros:
I can only speak for my department (Computer Science and Informatics, CSI)

Join if you're absolutely sure about your research plan. There would be no short of resources that you might need to conduct your research. Faculties and HoD are very supportive. 

You'll get involved in occasional short term projects which will pay you extra.

cons:
Absolutely no guidance, if you think that you'll be guided throughout your degree, it's not the place. You're on your own. 

Average students' standard is pretty low and the university policy is more of appeasing them to have good reviews in NSS than challenging them to become capable engineers. Therefore, if you love semi-supervised teaching, you might feel a bit disappointed.

No placement support from the school nor from the university for PhDs.

job_title: Senior Digital Content & Engagement Officer in London, England
pros: The teams were a delight to work with, both our own and when contacting others. It came from a collective unity against the cons, so we all just... got on, and got on with it.
cons: Management structure was awful. Zero accountability for poor performance in staff - one of my colleagues was rarely at the office, terrible in their actual role, but it was easier to keep them around (and blocking development of our team) because they were set in their ways. I took one week off for mental health reasons, following severe illness of a parent, and was told that it wasn't a "good enough" reason for the time off. Both these members of staff were made redundant I'm told, however the new management system in the Marketing Department has driven out many of the decent, hardworking members of staff, and it's widely known that most new members of staff brought in were mates with the new Director. Poisonous place to work for a career. Very slow to offer development opportunities, even for the most determined.

pros: Working with students, many of whom are from disadvantaged background, in order to improve their future. Central location meant it was a good place to network with other universities and the industry.
cons:
Management has no clue or desire to maintain academic achievement for students despite the best intentions of lecturers. Underachieving students are often retained in order to better student progression rate, but support to staff in order to help underachieving students are often denied. 

LSBU is also a boys club. Was told that I was not able to be promoted because I lacked a certain experience (which was a total bull), only for a male colleague to be promoted despite lacking that certain experience. In fact said male colleague was promoted despite having no background in teaching or experience in industry. His best friends however are all his male colleagues at upper management level, something I lacked. 

Absolutely no career progression for majority of people working there, only the elite few white males who has contacts with upper management.

review_title: Forward thinking and focused on students
pros: A dynamic forward looking university with a desire to innovate and try new things.  Always focused on improving the student experience and creating the best opportunities for them as graduates ensuring they achieve their best potential.  LSBU cares about its students and everyone goes the extra mile to support them as individuals.  Diversity is welcomes and supported.
cons: There are always a lot of things happening - a lot of projects and processes can create a heavy workload, so the ability to prioritise is crucial.  The ambition of the university and desire to be the best results in a lot of additional work, but you are empowered to make a difference.

pros:
-The university's in-house recruitment agency gives students more opportunities to grow their job prospects and work closely with academic and professional teams within the university.  This has also been backed by the university becoming the University of Year for 2 years running for Graduate Employment.

-The university is expanding focusing more attention on its colleges' group which could lead to further opportunities for career growth with staff if the right steps are taken in the future.

-The majority of staff members are friendly and always keen to go above and beyond for their respective stakeholders.
cons:
The downsides of working at London South Bank University

-ICT infrastructure needs improvement.  Often, systems are down or outdated. 

-Management needs to take Staff development more seriously and consider upskilling their staff to help improve staff retention. Too many staff members leave due to career progression. 

-The academic teams within the university have too much power over the strategic direction of the university. This leads to an imbalance of workloads assigned to other teams around the university. This also leads to a blame culture where teams are being blamed for tasks which they are not responsible for. This also leads to an issue in accountability, where management is not aware of who to call to account when issues arise.

There is something very special about the people at LSBU - approachable - down to earth and keen to create change.
